nodes.text: Leverage and the WACC with Taxes
There is another way we can incorporate the benefit of the firm’s future interest tax shield. Recall from
that for companies without preferred stock (which is most companies), we defined the WACC with taxes as:
Weighted Average Cost of Capital with Taxes

nodes.text: , we incorporate the benefit of the interest tax shield by adjusting the cost of debt to the firm. If the firm pays interest rate

nodes.text: for the pretax WACC, we can see that corporate taxes lower the effective cost of debt financing, which translates into a reduction in the weighted average cost of capital. In fact,

data.alt: r Subscript italic wacc Baseline equals ModifyingBelow r Subscript upper E Baseline StartFraction upper E Over upper E plus upper D EndFraction plus r Subscript upper D Baseline StartFraction upper D Over upper E plus upper D EndFraction With presentation form for vertical right brace Underscript Pretax WACC Endscripts minus ModifyingBelow r Subscript upper D Baseline upper T Subscript upper C Baseline StartFraction upper D Over upper E plus upper D EndFraction With presentation form for vertical right brace Underscript StartLayout 1st Row  Reduction Due 2nd Row  to Interest Tax Shield EndLayout Endscripts

nodes.text: Thus, the reduction in the WACC increases with the amount of debt financing. The higher the firm’s leverage, the more the firm exploits the tax advantage of debt and the lower its WACC.
illustrates this decline in the WACC with leverage. The figure also shows the pretax WACC as shown in

metadata.caption: We compute the WACC as a function of leverage using Eq. 16.9. Whereas the pretax WACC remains constant, with taxes the WACC declines as the firm increases its reliance on debt financing and the benefit of the interest tax deduction grows. The figure assumes a marginal corporate income tax rate of 20%.

config.caption: We compute the WACC as a function of leverage using Eq. 16.9. Whereas the pretax WACC remains constant, with taxes the WACC declines as the firm increases its reliance on debt financing and the benefit of the interest tax deduction grows. The figure assumes a marginal corporate income tax rate of 20%.
config.activityTitle: The WACC with and Without Corporate Taxes

config.title: Leverage and the WACC with Taxes

metadata.caption: We compute the WACC as a function of leverage using Eq. 16.9. Whereas the pretax WACC remains constant, with taxes the WACC declines as the firm increases its reliance on debt financing and the benefit of the interest tax deduction grows. The figure assumes a marginal corporate income tax rate of 20%.
